E donc cura aquela ayssi cum havem dit en la divisio e am aquo que es desus dit.	And thus cure it in this way as we have said in the division and with that which is written above.
De sectione super vermes generatos sub cute et dicitur aegritudo bovina.	About the generation of worms under the skin, and it is called bovine disease.
Aquesta malautia es nompnada en alcuna terra deves nos malautia bovina per so quar motas veguadas endeve als bious e es verm pauc un le qual es nat entre la codena e la carn, e va en tot le cos pujan e devalan, e es mostrat al sentiment deves le sieu anament de membre en membre entro que disromp la codena e yeys fora.	This disease is named in some land as our bovine disease because many times it comes from the oxen and it is a worm that is born between the skin and the flesh, and it goes throughout the whole body, destroying and corrupting, and it shows its sentiment by disarticulating the skin and eyes from member to member until it dismembers the skin and eyes.
E la generacio de lu es per putrefaccio de alcunas humors ayssi cum accideysso verms e serpentz e lombrics e ascaridas en le ventre.	And its generation is through the putrefaction of certain humors, thus causing worms and serpents and lumbrics and ascarids to appear in the belly.
E es temut per la malicia de lu, quar quan el va en le cors e es elevat al cap, e es pervengut al huel, lahoras fort leu uebre en lu e intra e destruzeys le huel, e aquo endeve motas veguadas.	And it is feared for its malice, because when it goes into the body and rises to the head, and reaches the brain, then it strongly affects it and destroys the brain, and that is why many times it comes.
E donc quan tu voles curar aquel e extraire lu, lahoras no se fa si no deves la sieua ambulacio e apparacio de lu al sentiment, e adonc cove que tu strenhas aquo que es sobre lu e aquo que es dejos lu am liament e constriccio fort, e aprop secca sobre lu e extratz aquel.	And thus when you want to cure it and extract it, then it cannot be done unless you have the ambulation and application of it to the sentiment, and then it is necessary that you strengthen what is above it and what is below it with ligament and constriction, and then you dry above it and extract it.
E si es preondat en la carn e no le atrobes, lahoras tu pausa cauteri am foc sobre le loc entro que mora, e la major causa que es temuda es corrupcio de lu am la qual corrump le loc ayssi cum havem dit.	And if it is embedded in the flesh and does not come out, then you apply cautery with fire on the area until it dies, and the main cause that is feared is corruption of it in the place where it corrupts the area as we have said.
May si tu vezes aquel esser pervengut al cap prop del huel, lahoras strenh sobre le sobrecil am fort strictura, e aprop secsa sobre lu, e extratz aquel; e cove que·l malaute use de mondificacio del sieu cors am medicinas evacuantz humors putridas malas, e guarda se de viandas generantz putrefaccio.	Perhaps it has reached the head because of the brain, then strengthen above the eyebrow with a strong structure, and then dry above it, and extract it; and it is necessary that the bad humor use the mondification of the entire body in medications evacuating putrid bad humors, and guard against the generation of putrefaction.
De sectione super aegritudinem nafir.	About the section on nafrid disease.
Aquesta malautia es nompnada en nostra terra nafir, e es dolor la qual ve en alcus membres, e aprop es permudada de membre en membre.	This disease is named in our land as nafrid, and it is the pain that appears in certain members, and then it spreads from member to member.
E yeu ja e vista aquela segon que yeu te recomtare.	And I have already seen that according to what I recommend to you.
Yeu fu apelat a una femna malauta ad una vila, e descubric le sieu bras e vi una imflacio petita en la vena funis del bras, e pus que fu romas per una hora, vi aquela imflacio anar ayssi cum va verm pujan ad aquest, mays pus leugierament que esser por, ayssi cum si fos argent viu quan corr de loc en loc.	I was called to a sick woman in a town, and I discovered her swollen arm and saw a small inflammation in the vein of the arm, and after I had been there for an hour, I saw that inflammation go away thus as it went down from this to that, but more lightly than it should be, thus as if it was silver I saw when it corroded from place to place.
E adonc anet s’en la dolor de aquel loc e fiquet se en le muscle, e aprop aqui stec per una hora.	And then I placed it in the pain of that place and fixed it in the muscle, and then I stayed there for an hour.
E aprop correc en l’autre cors entro que pervenc al autre bras.	And then I corrected it in the other body until it reached the other arm.
E aprop recomtec a mi que revolvia se per tot le cors sieu segon que yeu vi; e fo trop meravelat de la permutacio de lu e de la velocitat de membre en membre.	And then I recommended to myself that it revolve throughout the entire body according to what I had seen; and I was very marvelled at the permutation of it and at the velocity of member to member.
E yeu ja havia vist denant aquo en les mieus huels segon aquela manieyra, empero yeu he vistz motz les quals atroban dolor esser permutada de membra a membre.	And I had already seen this before in my own veins according to that manner, however I have seen many of those which cause pain to be permuted from member to member.
Mays no vi aquo am les huels ayssi cum en la femna.	But I did not see it in the veins thus as in the woman.
E yeu no cogiti esser aquo sino que es per aquo quar la femna era de viela, on so de secs cors e de venas descubertas, e en aquesta apparec al sentiment aquela ventositat permutada.	And I did not think it was that unless it was because the woman was old, one of dry body and discovered veins, and in this way it appears to the sentiment that permutated ventosity.
E es necessari que no apparesca segon aquesta retro-curacio en aquels que son delicioses e am cors humitz de venas ameguadas.	It is necessary that you do not appear to be retrograde in those who are delicate and have a humid constitution with weakened veins.
E cum tu voles la curacio de lu, e le pacient sent aquela dolor, lahoras no es a tu aparent al huel ayssi cum havem dit, lahoras tu strenh sobre aquel e dejos lu leugierament e secse sobre aquel entro que sia yssida aquela ventositat coartada, e cauterize le loc.	And when you want to cure them, and the patient feels that pain, then it is not apparent to you as we have said, then you strengthen over that and leave it for a long time and settle it with a gentle heat, and cauterize the area.
Mays si tu no la vezes am los tieus huels, alhoras tu cura aquel am excussio del cors e am aquo que expelleys ventositatz, e carmina aquelas am pillulas fetidas e am pillulas de serapi e semblantz.	Perhaps you do not always have the same ties to them, then you cure that which is excessive in the body and what expels bad humors, and clean those putrid and filthy ulcers and serpent-like sores.
De extraccio de sagetas.	From the extraction of arrows.
Sagetas son diversificadas segon las specias, e segon les locs dels cors en les quals cazo, quar la lor diversitat es que de aquellas so que han grans puntas, e petitas, e concavas, e sordas, so es solidas; e de lor so que han tres angles, e de aquelas a las quals so que han lenguas; e de aquelas a las quals so astelas.	Arrows are diversified according to species, and according to the places in the body where they occur, because their diversity is that of those with large points, and small ones, and concave, and rough, so they are solid; and of those with three angles, and of those which have tongues; and of those which have astellas (possibly "astellas" means "stars" or "stellate tips").
E aquela que es segon les membres e las pessas en las quals cazo es segon dos manieyras: quar les membres o so membres principals concaus, ayssi cum le cervel, le cor, e·l fitge, e le pulmo, e les ronhos, e les budels, e la vezica, e a lor semblantz; e donc quan catz en alcu de aquestz membres e aparo a tu senhals de mort, la qual causa yeu recomtare aprop, lahoras cove que tu evites extraccio de aquela sageta en aquels quar la mort siec aquel en le qual en las majors disposicios, e quan a tu no appareysso aquestz mals senhals, e la sageta no es amaguada en la profunditat del membre, lahoras tu extratz aquela e cura la plagua.	And that which is according to the members and the wounds in which they occur is according to two manners: because the members or principal members are concave, such as the brain, heart, liver, lung, kidneys, intestines, and bladder, and their likenesses; and therefore when you cut into one of these members and appear to sense death, which cause you to recommend a prompt cure, then it is necessary that you avoid extracting that arrow from those in which death sits in the major dispositions, and when you do not appear to have those evil symptoms, and the arrow is not embedded in the depth of the member, then you extract it and cure the plague.
E dels senhals del servel es quan catz en lu sageta, e trespassa le os, e es yssit del cyphac le qual es sobre le cervel, quar accideys per lu soda vehement, e scotomia, e vertige, e rogor en les huels, e imflamacio e rogor de la lengua, e spasme e permixtio de entendament e vomi de colera, e fort leu es abscindida la paraula e es destruida la votz, e es yssit del loc de la plagua humiditat blanca semblant a pols, e yeys de lu semblant ad aquositat de la carn.	And of the symptoms of the brain is when you cut into the arrow, and it passes through the bone, and it is situated on the crown of the head, because it causes vehement headache, and scotomia, and vertigo, and rigor in the veins, and inflammation and rigor of the tongue, and spasms and permutation of understanding and vomiting of cholera, and the vein is abscessed and the voice is destroyed, and it is situated on the place of the plague with white humid blisters resembling pustules, and it appears to be affected by the flesh.
E donc si appareyso a tu aquestz senhals, lahoras tu abste de la curacio e de la extraccio de la sageta, si non es fora.	And therefore if you appear to have these symptoms, then you abstain from the cure and extraction of the arrow, unless it is not outside.
Mays les senhals de la sageta quan catz en le cor, so que ela es prop de la mamila senestra, e sent am aquela quays sia ficada en causa dura, e no es causa vueda; e fort leu le movement de la sageta es semblant a movement del pols, e corr de la plagua sanc negra, e siec aquel fregiditat de las extremitatz, e suzor freja, e sincopi; e donc sapias que la mort descen ses tot dopte.	Perhaps the symptoms of the arrow when it cuts into the heart, so that it is near the left breast, and it seems as if it were fixed in a hard cause, and not a vain cause; and therefore the movement of the arrow is similar to the movement of the pulse, and it runs with the black plague, and it is a coldness of the extremities, and sweating freely, and syncopy; and therefore you know that death descends from all these signs.
E les senhals quan la sageta ha plaglat le pulmo so eyssiment de sanc spumos de la plagua, e les vayssels que so prop del col so apostematz, e es mudada la color del malaute, e expira sperit gran aut, e demanda atraccio de ayre freg.	And the symptoms when the arrow has affected the lung are expectoration of bloody spumous matter from the plague, and the veins that are near the colon become apostematous, and the color of the patient's skin is changed, and they exhale a great deal of spirit, and demand attraction of fresh air.
E si catz la sageta en le velament le qual es en le pietz, e la dolor lahoras es prop de las costas petitas, e es fayt le ale gran am vehement dolor e am sospir, e no so maugutz totz les membres dels muscles.	And if the arrow cuts into the peritoneum which is in the abdomen, and the pain then is near the small ribs, and it makes a great deal of vehement pain and anxiety, and does not move at all the members of the muscles.
E si catz la sageta en le stomac, lahoras fort leu yeys de la plagua vianda alcuna indigesta.	And if the arrow cuts into the stomach, then it is likely that you will have a plague of vomiting and some indigestion.
E si catz la sageta en le ventre, e es ficada en lu, yeys alcuna fenda de la plagua, o la tela, o budel le qual es disromput, e no es speransa en la curacio de lu extraccio de la sageta.	And if the arrow cuts into the abdomen, and it is fixed in it, you will have some ulceration of the plague, or the web, or hernia which is disrupted, and there is no hope in the cure of extracting the arrow.
E si la sageta catz en la vesica, e es yssida defora urina, e procesesca de lu alcuna causa a las partidas defora, e fort leu es dolor sobre le malaute, lahoras sapias que es mortal.	And if the arrow cuts into the bladder, and it is situated before the urine, and it processes some cause in the parts before, and therefore there is pain over the patient, then you know that it is mortal.
Mays les autres membres ayssi cum es la cara, le col, e·l golayro, e las spallas e le adjutori, e les spondils del dos, e la furcula, e la coysa, e la camba e a lor semblantz dels membres, son salvatz segon las majors disposicios quan la sageta no atroba vena ni arteria e no es sageta venenosa.	Perhaps the other members are also like the face, the neck, and the gullet, and the shoulders and the adjacent ones, and the vertebrae of the back, and the furcula, and the hip, and their likenesses among the members, are saved according to the major dispositions when the arrow does not touch a vein or artery and is not a poisonous arrow.
E yeu recomtare aquo a tu que he vist del esser de aquestas sagetas, per que signifiques per aquo sobre la curacio tieua.	And I recommend to you that you have seen the essence of these arrows, so that they signify to you about the cure that is suitable for it.
La qual causa es, quar en un home cazec sageta en le lacrimal del huel de lu en la razitz del nas, e yeu extrayssi aquela a lu del autra partida, dejos le grays de l’aurelha de lu, e es sanat, e no accidic en le huel de lu nocument.	The cause is, because in one case the arrow was cut into the lacrimal duct of the vein of the eye, and I extracted it from the other part, leaving the grayness of the aurelia of the eye, and it is healthy, and does not affect the eye's functioning.
E extrayssi autra sageta a un Juzeu la qual cazec en lu en lo grays del sieu huel, dejos la palpebra pus dejos, e la sageta ja era occultada e no so conseguit de aquela sino una petita extremitat am la qual adhereys al sieu fust, e era gran sageta de las sagetas agudas dels Turcs , am ferr leon en la qual no havia aurelhas.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew whose eye was cut into the grayness of his own vein, behind the eyelid, and the arrow was hidden and could not be reached except by a small extremity that adhered to the Jew's fist, and it was a great arrow among the sharp arrows of the Turks, with an iron point on which there were no aureliae.
E senat es le Juzieu , e no accidic en le sieu huel mal accident.	It is the judge, and do not neglect it in the sight of a bad accident.
E extrayssi una autra sageta a un home Crestia la qual era cazuta en le golayro, e era sageta arabica, e es aquela a la qual so aurelhas; e adonc yeu inscidegui sobre aquela entre doas guidegi, e ja era submersa en le golayro de lu; e adonc yeu so subtiliat am aquela, e aprop extraxi aquela, e es sanat le Crestia .	He extracted another arrow from a Christian man who had fallen into the gutter, and it was an Arabic arrow, and it was that which he had swallowed; and then you inserted it between two fingers, and it was submerged in the gutter of his body; and then you subtly felt around there, and then you extracted it, and it healed the Christian.
E extraxi autra sageta a un home la qual era cazuta en le sieu ventre, e cogitegui que moris per aquela; e donc, pus que foro passatz xxx dias e no es mudat sobre lu alcuna causa de las suas disposicios, inscidegui sobre la sageta e engenagui sobre aquela, e es sanat, e no accidic a lu accident mal.	He extracted another arrow from a man whose body had fallen into his own belly, and you thought he would die from it; and therefore, since he passed thirty days without any change in his condition, you inserted your fingers around the arrow and turned it around, and it healed, and do not neglect it due to bad accident.
E vi mays un home en le qual cazec una sageta en le dos de lu, e consolidada es la plagua sobre lu, e pus que foc aprop set ans, yssic la sageta en la razitz de la coyssa.	I saw a man in whom an arrow had fallen into his back, and the wound was consolidated over him, and since he had suffered for about seven years, I extracted the arrow from the root of the thigh.
E vi una femna a la qual cazec sageta en le sieu ventre, e la plagua es consolidada dedintz lu, e no es mudada en las suas disposicios en re, e la femna no atrobec nocument en alcunas de las suas opperacios naturals.	I saw a woman in whom an arrow had fallen into her belly, and the wound was consolidated inside her, and it did not change in her condition, and the woman did not have any movement in some of her natural functions.
E vi un autre home al qual cazec sageta en la sua cara e consolidada es la plagua e romas la sageta, no atrobant aqui mota dolor, e motz semblantz ad aquestz.	I saw another man in whom an arrow had fallen into his face and the wound was consolidated, and you removed the arrow, not feeling much pain, and many signs appeared to be like this.
E extrayssi la sageta del home dels princeps del rey que era cazuda en le mieg loc del nas sieu e ja havia declinat a la partida dreyta un petit, e occultada era tota la sageta.	He extracted the arrow from the man, one of the king's princes, which had fallen into his nose and had already declined to the right side a little, and the whole arrow was hidden.
E yeu fu appelat a la curacio de lu aprop le cazement de la sageta entro a tres dias.	And you were called for the cure of his wound caused by the falling of the arrow within three days.
E adonc yeu atrobegui la plagua de la sageta mot streyta; e adonc yeu inquirigui aquela am tenta subtil, e no sentigui aquela; mays el la sentia puncio dejos la aurelha dreyta, e adonc speregui que aquela punccio era per la extremitat de la sageta.	And then you felt the wound of the arrow very strongly; and then you inquired about it with a subtle touch, and did not feel it; but I felt it at the point below the right ear, and then you suspected that this point was due to the extremity of the arrow.
E amplastregui le loc am emplaustre en le qual es vertut atrectiva e digestiva, confizant de mi que·l loc se apostemes per que appares a mi le loc de la sageta, per que secces sobre aquela.	And I applied a plaster to the place where I had extracted with attractive and digestive powers, trusting in myself that the place would be cleansed so that it appears to me as the place of the arrow, so that it succeeds over it.
E no accidic en le loc accident significant que la sageta hagues conseguit aquel loc; e yeu continuegui am le emplaustre sobre lu per motz dias e no accidic accident; e consolidada es la plagua entretant, e romas le malaute de la extreccio de lu per spazi de motz dias entro que un jorn sentic la sageta dintz le sieu nas e recontec aquo a mi.	And do not neglect the significant place of the accident where the arrow had reached that place; and you continued to apply the plaster over it for many days without any accident; and the wound was consolidated meanwhile, and I removed the bad humor from the excretion of his body within many days until one day I felt the arrow inside his nose and recognized it as my own.
E adonc yeu pausegui sobre la plagua medicina acuta corrosiva per motz dias entro que foc ubert, e am la tenta yeu assagegui aquel, e atrobegui la extremitat de la sageta subtil, la qual adhereys al fust.	And then you applied a sharp corrosive medicine to the wound for many days until it became open, and I touched it with my finger, and felt the extremity of the arrow subtly, which adhered to the skin.
E aprop yeu ajustegui en la apersio de la plagua per aquela medicina acuta entro que apparec a mi visiblament la extremitat de la sageta, e passec a mi temps am aquo per le spazi de temps entro quatre meses.	And then you adjusted it in the opening of the wound with that sharp medicine until it appeared to me visibly the extremity of the arrow, and I took time for myself about that for the space of four months.
E aprop pus que la plagua foc amplificada, e foc a mi possible entrometre las forfexs en lu, e remaure aquela, e no obezic ad eyssiment, lahoras yeu no cessegui subtiliar e ingeniar sobre aquela am manieyras de engen, entro que comensegui un dia sobre aquela am manieyras de engens pendre lu am forceps descentment faytas, segon que vindra la forma de aquelas en la fi del capitol, entro que extraxi aquela; e aprop restauregui aquela plagua.	And then since the wound became amplified, and it was possible for me to introduce the forceps into it, and I remained there, and did not obey the judgment, because you did not cease to subtly ingeniate and engineer about that in many ways of art, until one day began on that in many ways of art, pending to take it out with forceps skillfully made, according to what will be seen at the end of the chapter, until I extracted it; and then I restored the wound.
E alcus metges jutgavan que la cartillage del nas no es restaurada, e yeu restauregui aquela e la plagua es consolidada, e sanat es le malaute per sanetat entiera, e no noguec en lu en deguna causa.	And some doctors judged that the cartilage of the nose was not restored, and you restored it and the wound was consolidated, and it healed entirely, and I did not find any fault in it for any reason.
E yeu recomti a tu la qualitat de extraccio de alcunas sagetas per que pauses aquo regla e significacio sobre aquo que no he dit, quar las partidas de aquesta art e las difinicios de aquela no so conprehendudas am narracio ni no comprehen aquelas le libre.	And you recommend to yourself the quality of extracting some arrows because you paused on that rule and significance about what I have not said, since the parts of this art and its definitions are not understood in narration nor do they comprehend it freely.
E le artifexs savi compara am pauc sobre mot; e am aquo que es present sobre aquo que es absent; e atroba operacio novela e instrument novel deves le descendement de las causas extranhas del art quan accideysso.	And the artisans knew how to compare few things about many; and I know what is present about what is absent; and they found a new operation and new instrument of descent from the external causes of the art when they happen.
E donc yeu dic que sagetas no son fora-gitadas dels membres en les quals son ficadas sino segon dos manieyras: o per atraccio del loc en le qual intrec; o per le contrari de la autra partida.	And therefore you say that arrows are not forgotten in the members where they are fixed, but rather in two ways: either by attraction to the place where they entered; or by contrast with the other part.
E aquela que es gitada per le loc don es intrada, o es sageta procedent en loc carnos, e es atirada e fora-gitada.	And that which is forgotten by the place where it entered, or it is an arrow proceeding from a fleshy place, and it is attracted and forgotten.
E si no obezeys a eyssiment de la hora en la qual catz, lahoras cove que tu la laysses per alcus dias entro que poyresca la carn que es al enviro de lu, e sia alleujada l‘atraccio de lu e la sua egressio.	And if you do not obey the judgment of the hour in which it falls, then it is necessary that you leave it for some days until the flesh that is around it becomes healthy, and its attraction and exit are alleviated.
E semblantment si es ficada en os e no obezeys a tu a eyssiment, lahoras layssa aquela per alcus dias e itera aquela am atraccio e mocio en quascun dia, e ja es fora-gitada.	And similarly if it is fixed in the bone and does not obey your judgment, then leave it for some days and try to attract it with motion on any day, and then it will be forgotten.
E si no obezeys a tu eyssiment aprop alcus dias, lahoras cove que tu perforas en le circuit de la sageta en aquel os de tota partida am taravel subtil entro que·l loc sia amplificat de la sageta, e aprop extratz aquela.	And if you do not obey your own judgment, then beware that you do not perforate the circuit of the sage in that bone of the entire affected part, so that the subtle travel within does not amplify the sage, and then extract it.
E si la sageta es ficada en le os del cap e ja ha procezit en un dels ventres del cervel, e apparo en le malaute alcus de aquels accidentz les quals yeu e ditz, lahoras abste de la extraccio de la sageta e layssa aquela entro que·l sieu esser sia equat aprop alcus dias; quar si la sageta perve al ciphac, lahoras la mort no es a lu prolonguada.	And if the sage is fixed in the bone of the head and has proceeded to one of the vents of the brain, and appears in the patient's accidents which you have and tell, then abstain from the extraction of the sage and let it be until the sight can be equalized; for if the sage pervades the ciphalic, then death is not prolonged.
E si la sageta no es ficada sino en le cors del os tant solament e no passa entro al ciphac, e roman le malaute per alcus dias, e no accideys a lu denguna causa de aquels accidentz, lahoras tu engenia en la atraccio de la sageta e en la atraccio de lu.	And if the sage is not fixed but only in the body of the bone, and does not pass into the ciphalic, and the patient remains for some days, and no accident occurs due to any of those causes, then engage in the attraction of the sage and in the attraction of it.
Mays si es mot ficada e no obezeys a tu a extraccio, lahoras tu aministra taravels en le circuit de la sageta ayssi cum havem recomtat, e aprop cura le loc entro que sia sanat.	Perhaps it is not fixed and does not obey your extraction, then you administer travels in the circuit of the sage as we have recommended, and then cure the area until it is healthy.
Mays si la sageta ja es amaguada en le loc del cors, e es amaguada del sentiment, lahoras tu inquireys aquela am tenta, e si tu sentas aquela, lahoras atira aquela am alcus sturmentz les quals so convenientz a la atraccio de lu.	Perhaps the sage is accumulated in the area of the body, and it is accumulated from the sentiment, then you inquire into that accumulation, and if you feel it, then attract it with certain instruments which are convenient for its attraction.
E si no podes sobre lu per la constriccio de la plagua e per la longitut del preon, e aqui no es os ni nervi ni vena, lahoras tu fen sobre la plagua entro que sia amplificada e que sia possible extrayre la sageta.	And if you do not operate on it due to the constriction of the plague and the length of the pression, and here there is neither bone nor nerve nor vein, then feel upon the plague until it is amplified and it is possible to extract the sage.
E si so a lu aurelhas am las quals sia tenguda, lahoras tu deliura la carn en la qual es ficada de tota partida am tot le engen que poyras far; e ingenia sobre aquo, si no podes sobre la evasio de la carn en la fractura de las aurelhas e en torssio de aquelas entro que obezesca.	And if you have the aurelia which holds it, then you deliver the flesh in which it is fixed from the entire affected part to the very end that you can do; and operate upon that, if you cannot operate on the evasion of the flesh in the fracture of the aurelia and in twisting of those until it obeys.
E quan tu administras la extraccio de la sageta en quascun loc on sia, lahoras tu usa am torcio de la tua ma am forceps a totas partidas entro que fassa aquela obezir; e subtilia am deriera subtilitat que la sageta no sia trencada e que sia fayta a tu dificil atraccio de lu e de aquela extraccio.	And when you administer the extraction of the sage in any location where it is, then use a torque of your hand with forceps on all affected parts until it makes it obey; and subtly use a subtle subtlety so that the sage is not torn and it is made difficult for you to attract it and its extraction.
E si no podes sobre aquela de la tua hora, lahoras tu layssa per alcus dias entro que se poyrescan las partidas que so en le circuit de lu, e aprop itera aquela quar lahoras es alleujada.	And if you cannot operate on it at your time, then leave it for some days until the parts that are in its circuit can be restored, and then iterate upon it because then it is alleviated.
Mays si a tu fa contrarietat flux de sanc, lahoras tu administra aquo que havem dit de curacio en le sieu capitol.	Perhaps you have made a contrary flow of blood, then administer what we have said about cure in the seventh chapter.
E guarda la tua vertut de inscizio de vena o de nervi, o de corda, e aministra engen en tota manieyra a tu possibla de la evasio de la sageta; e fay aquo am facilitat e tranquillitat e tarditat e fermetat ayssi cum yeu e a tu recomtat.	And guard your virtue of incision of vein or nerve, or cord, and administer skill in all manner possible for the evasion of the sage; and make it facilitated and tranquilized and delayed and firmified as you have recommended.
E donc que fassas contrayre la sageta per so que·l malaute sia segon la figura segon la qual foc deves le cazement de la sageta en lu, quar es mays juvatiu.	And thus you make counter to the sage so that the patient is according to the figure according to which they must remove the encumbrance of the sage from it, because it is perhaps more juvenile.
Mays si aquo no es a tu possible, lahoras tu aministra aquo que es a tu possible per las figuras.	Perhaps if that is not possible for you, then administer what is possible for you according to the figures.
Mays las sagetas que son fora-gitadas per le contrari del autra partida, o que ja de lu procezeys alcuna partida a las partidas de fora, o fa gilbositat la extramitat de la sageta per sentiment de la partida pus desus de la codena propdana e vezes aquela eminent; adonc tu secsa sobre aquela; e sia la seccio segon la quantitat en la qual prenguan las forceps; e aprop atira aquela, quar ela es fayta leugiera a eyssiment.	Perhaps the sages that are forgotten by the contrary of another affected part, or which has already proceeded to some part outside, or has made the extrication of the sage by sentiment of the part above the codena propdan and times that eminent; then you section upon that; and it is the section according to the quantity in which they take the forceps; and then attract it, because it is made lighter to the judgment.
Mays si es retenguda en le os, lahoras tu tortz lama segon contrarietat entro que la sageta enprema en le os, e amplifique a si meteys, e aprop extratz aquela.	Perhaps it is retained in the bone, then twist the lame according to contrarity until the sage takes root in the bone, and amplify its measurements, and then extract it.
E sino, layssa aquela per alcus dias, e aprop itera aquela entro qu’en yesca.	And if not, leave it for some days, and then iterate upon it until you find what is sought.
E si le fust de la sageta es en aquela, lahoras tu impelleys aquela am lu.	And if the foundation of the sage is in that, then implant it in the body.
Mays si le fust es cazut e voles aministrar inpulsio, lahoras tu intromet e aquela, si es sorda, sturment concau per so que intre la concavitat de lu en la coa de la sageta e aprop impelleys aquela am lu.	Perhaps if the foundation is fallen and you want to administer impulse, then introduce and into that, if it is dull, instrument concert with the cavity of the body in the case of the sage and then implant it in the body.
Mays si la sageta es concava, lahoras tu impelleys aquela am sturment fort intrant en aquela, quar la sageta es alleujada per aquela.	Perhaps if the sage is concave, then implant it in the instrument strongly inserted into that, because the sage is alleviated by that.
E si la sageta es entoxiguada, lahoras cove que tu concaves tota la carn en la qual es le vere, si es a tu possible aquo, e aprop cura aquela am aquo que si conveneys.	And if the sage is intoxicated, then beware that you concave all the flesh in which it is true, if it is possible for you, and then cure it with what is convenient.
E si la sageta catz en le pietz, o en le ventre, o en la vesica, o en le costat, e es propinqua per so que tu tocas aquela am la tenta, e es a tu possible secsar sobre aquela, lahoras secsa sobre aquela e guarda te de inscizio de vena o de nervi, e extratz aquela, e aprop cos la plagua si indigeys, e cura aquela entro que sia sanada.	And if the sage is located in the feet, or in the belly, or in the bladder, or in the ribs, and it is near so that you touch it with your hand, and it is possible for you to section upon that, then section upon that and guard yourself from incision of vein or nerve, and extract it, and then heal the plague if it is indigent, and cure it until it is healthy.
Forma de forceps am las quals so atiradas las sagetas:	Form of forceps which are attracted to the sages:
Sian las extremitatz de lor cum a bec de ausel que son faytas cum serra quan prendon sobre la sageta per so que no la layssen.	If the extremities of their body are like a bird's beak which are affected with cold humors when they take hold of the arrow for fear of not releasing it.
E de aquelas son faytas motas specias, grans, paucas e migieras, segon la quantitat de la grandeza de la sageta e de la sieua pauqueza, e de la amplitud de la plagua, e de la constriccio de lu.	And of those are affected special motes, large, few and smaller, according to the quantity of the greatness of the arrow and of its slight weakness, and of the amplitude of the plague, and of its constriction.
Forma de impellent concau de aquesta extremitat conquava ayssi cum pena de ausel per so que sia alleujat le intrament de la sageta en lu, e impulcio de aquela sorda:	Form of impulse with a concave shape of this extremity that is conquered thus with the penalty of a bird's beak so that it alleviates the instrument of the arrow in it, and impulse of that cord.
Forma de impellent de sorda extremitat:	Form of impulse of a cord-like extremity:
ayssi cum ray per so que sia alleujat le intrament de lu en la sageta concava e es impellida am aquel.	thus with a ray so that it alleviates the instrument in it through the concave arrow and it is impelled at that moment.
De fleubotomia de las venas.	Of the phlebotomy of the veins.
Las venas de fleubotomia de las quals corr costuma de fleubotomar so .xxx., de las quals so en le cap .xvi., so es doas venas pulsatils las quals so aprop las aurelhas, dic alhasisain; doas herbas que so en les dos templars apparentz; e doas venas que so en dos lacrimals de dos huels que son appeladas aspicientz; e la vena preparada en le mieg loc del front, e la vena que es en la extremitat del nas; e doas guidegi que so al col; e doas venas que so en la labia desus; e doas venas que so en la labia dejos; e — aquestas so las venas que so appeladas algelic —; e so doas venas que so dejos la lengua.	The veins of phlebotomy of those that customarily run to be phlebotomized thus. of those that are in the head, 16. it is two pulsating veins that are near the ears, they say alhasisain; two herbs that are in the two temples apparent; and two veins that are in the two lacrimal ducts of two eyes that are called aspicientz; and the vein prepared in the middle of the forehead, and the vein that is at the extremity of the nose; and two guides that are at the neck; and two veins that are under the upper lip; and two veins that are under the lower lip; and — these are the veins that are called algelic —; and it is two veins that are beneath the tongue.

Sanguissuguas no so administradas en motz membres sino en les membres en les quals non es possible posicio de ventosas, per la parvitat de aquels, ayssi cum le pot e gingiva e semblantz a lor; o en membre denudat de carn, ayssi cum le dit e·l nas e lors semblantz.	Blood-letting is not administered in many members except in those members where it is not possible to place cupping glasses, due to their smallness, such as the vein and gum, which seem like them; or in a member denuded of flesh, such as the finger and nose, and thus they seem.
E la qualitat de usar de aquelas que si has trobadas sanguisugas que so en las ayguas dossas de poyredura mundas.	And the quality of using those that you have found blood-letting cups that are on the dirty and polluted parts of the body.
E aprop sian layssadas le dia e la nueyt en aygua dossa entro que sian famolentas, e que no romangua alcuna causa en le ventre de aquelas; e aprop sia evacuat le cors en le comensament am fleubotomia e am ventozas; e aprop fregua le membre del malaute entro que s’enrojezesca; e aprop sian pausadas sobre lu.	And then they are washed with dirty water during the day and night until they are famished, and that no remaining cause is in the belly of those; and then the body is evacuated through flebotomy and cupping glasses; and then the member of the patient is cooled until it becomes red; and then they are placed over it.
E cum son umplidas e caso.	And since they are filled and in a case.
E si es possible succio del loc am ventoza, es mays derier en juvament.	And if it is possible to suck from the place with the cupping glass, it is better to delay in juvenation.
E sino, lahoras lava le loc am vi agre e aprop am mota aygua; e sia freguat e expremut.	And if not, then wash the place with wine and then with much water; and it is cooled and extracted.
E si es prolonguat le cors del sanc aprop le cazement de las sanguissuguas, e es aquo resudan, lahoras tu enfon un drap de li en aygua freja, e pausa aquel de sobre entro que sia abdida la resudacio.	And if the body of the blood is prolonged by the administration of blood-letting cups, and it is that which remains, then you put a piece of cloth in cold water, and place that over it until the remaining fluid is absorbed.
E si le sanc es multiplicat, lahoras polveriza sobre lu vitriol trissat, o guallas e semblantz a lor de las causas stipticas, entro que·l sanc sia abscidit; o sian pausadas sobre le loc las maytatz de favas excocicadas, e sian layssadas entro que las favas aderescan al loc, e es le sanc abscidit.	And if the blood is multiplied, then powder over it with vitriol thrice, or gall and similarly to them of the stiptic causes, until the blood is abscessed; or place over the location the mastics of excruciated beans, and they are washed until the beans adhere to the location, and the blood is abscessed.
E cove, si es necessaria, iteracio de sanguissuguas, quan es possible mudar aquelas.	And it is necessary, if required, to repeat the blood-letting, when it is possible to change them.
E si las sanguissuguas son prohibidas de suspenssio, lahoras sia freguat le loc am sanc recent o fique una agulha en les locs entro que yesca sanc; e aprop sian pausadas, quar aquelas quan sento alcun sanc tantost adarysso.	And if the blood-letting cups are prohibited from suspension, then cool the place with recent blood or fix a needle in the places until blood is obtained; and then they are placed, because those who feel any blood at all adhere to it.
E quan voles que cajan, polveriza sobre aquelas un pauc de aloen trissat, o sal, o cendre, e cazo tantost.	And when you want them to fall, powder over them a little of thrice-tried aloe, or salt, or cinder, and it will happen soon.
Ayssi comensa lo prolec de la tersa partida: de restauracio.	Thus begins the third part: on restoration.
Aquest capitol es motas veguadas necessari en la art de medicina; e es restauracio de fractura e de dislocacio accident en les osses.	This chapter is very necessary in the art of medicine; and it is about the restoration of fracture and accidental dislocation in the bones.
O, filh, sapiatz que jactan se de aquest capitol les fols metges e les vulguars e aquels que degun temps no reguardero les libres dels Antics ni legiro de aquels una letra.	Oh, son, you know that they throw away this chapter, the foolish doctors and the vulgar ones, and those who for a long time did not regard the books of the Ancients nor read a single letter.
E per aquesta causa es fayt que aquesta manieyra dels scients in terra nostra es privat; e yeu no ho e obliat en aquo degun temps be de tot; e no he adhibit aquo que apres, sino per longitut de lectio dels libres dels Antics e studi sobre le entendement de aquels, entro que extrayssi la sciencia de aquels.	And for this reason it is made that this manner of the sciences in our land is private; and you do not have it and have forgotten it all at once; and no one has inhabited it since, except by length of reading of the books of the Ancients and study on the understanding of those, until they extract the science from them.
E aprop adirigui a experiment e studi en la longitut de la mieua vida.	And then I will direct an experiment and study in the length of my own life.
E yeu ja he de aquo descrit en aquest capitol tot aquo que conte la mieua sciencia e sobre le qual es passat lo mieu experiment; pus que agui abreujat aquo a vos autres e deliuregui aquo de occupacio de elonguacio; e abreujegui aquo en la fi de abreujacio; et e monstrat aquo en la fi de declaracio; e formegui en aquo motas formas dels sturmentz que so administratz en aquel, cum es fayt per addicio de declaracio, ayssi cum he fayt en dos capitols precedentz.	And I have already described in this chapter all that contains my science and about which I have passed my experiment; since I have abbreviated it for you others and delivered it from occupation of prolongation; and I will abbreviate it at the end of abbreviation; and I will show it at the end of declaration; and I will form it in many forms of the instruments that are administered in it, as is done by addition of declaration, thus I have done in two preceding chapters.
Capitol primier.	First chapter.
Summae et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fraftorum et diversorum si uniuscuiusque.	Summary and collections from being broken bones, from which the necessary preliminary is, before we begin the remembrance of fractured members and diverse ones.
Cove donc que diguam en le prohemi de aquest capitol las summas del sermo; e les capitols al entendament dels quals en le comensament es forsat le artifexs e a stacio sobre la veritat de aquels; so es vos e aquels que so promptz que sapian o aprenguan aquesta art nobla autres de vos.	Therefore, we will discuss in the proem of this chapter the summaries of the sermon; and the chapters to the understanding of those which from the beginning are forced by the artisans and stationed over the truth of these; so it is you and those that are so prompt that they know or apprehend this noble art better than you.
E donc dic que quan accideys a alcu fractura o dislocacio o torcio o cazement, lahoras cove que tu te coytes al comensament am fleubotomia o aleyar aquel, o quascu ensemps, si no prohibeys alcuna causa, ayssi cum debelitat de vertut, o es aquel al qual accideys effant, o viel en decrepitat, o es temps de vehement calor, o de vehement freg.	And therefore it is said that when accidents occur due to fracture or dislocation or twisting or fall, then it is known that you should begin with flebotomy or alleviation of that, or some remedies, if no cause prohibits, and thus with debilitation of virtue, or it is that which occurs suddenly, or it is in decrepit state, or it is a time of vehement heat, or of vehement cold.
E aprop sia content en vianda sieua de erbas frejas e de carns de auzels e de crabotz; e prohibem carns grossas e umplir si de viandas e de tota vianda que umple las venas de sanc, entro que siras segurat de apostema caut, e si no temes efusio de materia al membre.	And then be content with a diet of fresh herbs and lean meats of birds and crabs; and prohibit gross meats and fill up on diets and entire diets that fill the veins with blood, so that you will be secure from apostemeous ulcers, and if you do not fear effusion of matter to the members.
E lahoras retorne le malaute al sieu regiment primier am le qual corr costuma de lu.	And then return the patient to their first regimen as is customary for them.
E donc cum le os trencat comensa esser restaurat, lahoras cove que·l malaute sia pascut de viandas nutritivas de nutriment mot e gros e greu en les quals sia viscositat, ayssi cum so viandas faytas de froment cueyt am aygua, e ris, e caps, e pes, e ventres de vacas, e huous, e peys fresc, e vi gros e semblants ad aquels, e am aquest regiment es fayta coagulacio de fractura pus leugierament e miels.	And then when the broken bone begins to be restored, then it is known that the patient should be fed with nutritious diets of subtle and light nutriment, and not viscous, such as those diets made from flour, water, rice, cabbage, peas, fresh fish, and similar things, and in this regimen there is a coagulation of fracture pus, which is easier to heal.
E sapias que les osses trinquatz quan so en les homes que so en la primiera vilura e en los decrepitz, no es possible que sian continuatz e sian consolidatz segon lur natura per la exsiccacio dels membres de lor.	And you know that the broken bones, when they are in the old men who are in the first weakness and in the decrepit states, it is not possible that they can continue and be consolidated according to their nature through the desiccation of their members.
E son consolidatz e continuatz segon lor natura tot temps per la exsiccacio de aquels membres, e so continuatz e consolidatz aquels que so de lor en la fi de la lenitat, ayssi cum les osses dels petitz effantz.	And they are consolidated and continued according to their nature all the time through the desiccation of those members, and they continue and consolidate those that are of theirs at the end of the length, just like the bones of small children.
Mays empero natura ajusta e amnecteys sobre le os trencat de tota partida alcuna causa semblant a glut en le qual es grossitut que adhereys e strenh aquel entro que so ensemps conglutinatz e liatz ensemps, entro que venen la fi de fortitut e de fermesa, ayssi cum foc al comensament, entro que denguna causa no prohibeys aquel de las suas obres.	But the Emperor Nature adjusts and connects above the broken bone of the whole party any cause similar to glue in which it is grossly that adheres and strengthens until they are conglomerated and united, until they reach the end of fortitude and firmness, just like a focus at the beginning, until no cause prohibits that from their works.
E per aquesta causa es necessari que pauses las viandas del malaute, viandas en las quals so gravitat e viscozitat e grosseza, ayssi cum havem dit.	And for this reason it is necessary that you pause the diets of the patient, diets in which there are gravity and viscosity and grossness, just as we have said.
Mota diversitat de fractura segon diversitat del membre.	A variety of fracture according to the variety of the member.

And you know that the species of fracture are diverse according to the diversity of the members, for a fracture of the bone of the leg is different from the fracture of the bone of the head; and the fracture of the bone of the foot is different from the fracture of the bone of the back; and similarly all the other members are diverse among themselves.

And the species of fracture of the bone are diversified in their own measures; for there is a curved fracture other than that which occurs in the stars; and some veiled ones are made into fractures according to the length of the bone: and so the fractures of the sagittal and stellar and additional proceeding and not-proceeding, just as it is made in the pain when it is prepared to write, and it is a fracture with plague and disruption in the head, and it is a fracture of small fissure.

Mota senhal de fractura del os.	A sign or indication of fracture of the bone.
E per aquo es conoguda fractura del os: es tortuositat de lu, e de aquel eminencia e appericio de lu al sentiment, e so de lu quan compremes aquel am la tua ma.	And for that reason it is known as fracture of the bone: it is a twistedness of it, and of its prominence and appearance to the sentiment, and so of it when it comprises that with your hand.

Mays si en le os so satagias, lahoras es necessaria extencio de aquest membre trencat de doas partz, si es la ma o le pe; o am la tua ma si le membre es petit; o am doas cordas o am una corda e la ma.	Perhaps in the bones so shattered, then extension of this broken member from two parts is necessary, whether it's the hand or the foot; or you have your hand if the member is small; or use two cords or a cord and the hand.

And beware that you don't fall on the patient during your operation, neither injuring nor lesioning; and perform according to your gentle power that you apply one bone with another, its companion, according to their best forms.

And avoid vehement extension and compression, thus as many foolish doctors who make vain attempts to accelerate aposteme with their operation, or make counter-operations on the member, thus as we have seen through the operations of their vain attempts.
E aprop annecteys, aprop equacio e decent operacio e strictura de aquel membre, e repaus e tranquilitat; amoneste le malaute sobre aquo e fay le squivar que no maugua aquel en la hora de las suas vigilias e del sieu dormir, e ves la sua revolucio e agitacio, e deves la sua egestio, e deves totz les sieus movementz am tota la sua vertut; e aguarda se que la posicio del membre sia posicio am la qual sia asegurada la dolor, la qual causa es quar quan sent en la disposicio de la posicio del membre delor o lesio; lahoras cove que permutes aquel ad autra disposicio de aquela am la qual non senta dolor; e guarda am aquo que la posicio de lu aquela sia dreyta e engual, per so que al membre non accida tortuositat quan es restaurat.	And then connect, adjust and perform a decent operation and structuring of that member, and rest and tranquility; advise the patient about it and make them avoid moving it during their vigils and sleep, and see its revolution and agitation, and remove its ejection, and remove all its movements with total virtue; and beware that the position of the member is a position in which pain is ensured, which cause is because one feels in the disposition of the position of the member or lesion; then it's good to change it to another disposition where no pain is felt; and take care that the position of it is direct and equal, so that the member doesn't acquire tortuosity when it's restored.

And the quality of the structure of the tranquil member is that which you have recommended; because you know that broken members are diversified in their smallness and greatness and in the form of those.

Perhaps those that are large, such as the hip or the leg, it's good that in those there be a hard and durable wrapping, because the strong connection connects the big member and strengthens it entirely with equal structure, so that in it no bruise enters.

And then begin, adjust your evacuation of equality, pause a suitable ligament according to that, above the place of that fracture with three wrappings or four according to the member's merit; and strengthen your hand a little on the ligament.

And then see that it is in that part above the place of the fracture, and strengthen yourself so that you don't force your structure on the place of the fracture.
E aprop elongua te am envolucio del loc de la fractura un pauc, e mollifiqua la strictura petit a petit, entro que prenguas del loc sa una gran partida.	And then elongate yourself in the wrapping of the place of the fracture a little, and soften the small structure little by little, until you take hold of the place with a great part.
E aprop pren una autra benda e envolveys aquela autra veguada sobre le loc trenquat am envolucio, e aprop ve am las envolucios a la partida pus dejos de la fractura; e sia la tua operacio en la strictura de la envolucio e en mollificacio de aquela segon que havem dit en la envolucio primieyra desus.	And then take another bandage and wrap it around the broken place with wrapping, and then see that the wrappings are on the part below the fracture; and be your operation in the structure of the wrapping and in softening of it according to what we have said in the primary wrapping above.
E aprop pausa entre las volucios de stopa leon o drap am le qual sia engualada la tortuositat de la fractura, si en lu es tortuositat; e sino, no pauses en lu alcuna causa.	And then pause between the turns of wrapping with a smooth cloth or fabric on which the tortuosity of the fracture is equalized, if there is tortuosity in it; and otherwise, don't pause in it for any cause.
E aprop pausa sobre lu autra benda, e aprop enguala sobre aquestas envolucios stelhas decentment faytas tantost, si en le loc no es imflacio o apostema caut, e lahoras pausa sobre lu aquo que sede le apostema aquel e que oste la imflacio; e layssa aquela per alcus jorns; e lahoras tu strenh sobre lu las stelhas.	And then pause on the other bandage, and then equalize on these wrappings decently made so far, if in the place there is no inflammation or aposteme, and then pause on it which sits the aposteme that and stops the inflammation; and leave it like that for some days; and then you strengthen on the wrapping.

Empero cove que la astelha que es pausada sobre aquela fractura sia pus grossa e pus lada un petit que las autras astelhas, e la longitut de la stela segon qu’es legut al membre en magnitut e parvitat; e aprop strenh sobre las astelhas am autra benda segon la tua primieyra strictura; e aprop lia desus am fiel decentment segon que havem dit de strictura, e es que sia la tua strictura segon le loc de la fractura mes, e quant mes es alonguat de la fractura, es mendre la strictura.	However, it's good that the wrapping which is paused on that fracture be a little thicker and stronger than the other wrappings, and the length of the stake according to what is suitable for the member in greatness and smallness; and then strengthen on the wrappings with another bandage according to your primary structure; and then bind below decently as we have said about structure, and it's that your structure be according to the place of the fracture itself, and when more is aligned from the fracture, it's lessened the structure.
E cove que les fils sian migiers en grossesa e subtilitat, e sian de li mol; e si les fils so grosses, ayssi cum yeu he vist per la operacio de alcus fols pausantz les lors fils de cordas de li tort, e es error gran, quan catz la strictura fora equalitat.	And it's good that the threads be medium in thickness and subtlety, and be of soft wool; and if the threads are thick, thus as you have seen through the operation of some foolish doctors pausing the threads of twisted cords of wool, and it's a great error, when one doesn't hold the structure for equality.
E eyssament fils subtils no so convenientz, quar tu no consaguiras per strictura am aquels aquo que voles, e no cove que entre astela e astela haja mens de un dit.	And in this way the subtle remedies are not so convenient, because you do not constrict them by strict structure as those that you want, and it does not happen that between this and that there is less than a day's worth.
E si le malaute es ledit per las extremitatz de las stelas aprop la strictura en les locs sas, lahoras pausa dejos aquelas de stopa leon o lana carmenada entro que aquo no li fassa lesio.	And if the patient is led by the extremities of the stars to put structure in their places, then stop those of stopping the lion or the caramelized entrails so that it does not make a lesion.
Alcunas veguadas fractura es am plagua, e accideys disrupcio en la codena, e yeu vindre am rememoracio en aquela en le capitol segon singularitat.	Some broken fractures are a plague, and accidents cause disruption in the code, and you will find a reminder in that chapter according to singularity.
E sapias que ges tot membre trencat no es streyt am stelhas al primier dia; la qual causa es quar le membre, quan es gran, no cove que pauses sobre lu stelhas sino aprop v dias o vii o mays, segon la tua seguratat de adveniment de apostema caut.	And you know that not all broken members are straight on the first day; the cause is because the member, when it's large, does not fit onto the stars until about five or seven days, according to your secure advancement of abscess caution.
E aquesta es la manieyra dels emplaustres am les quals les Antics restauravan, les quals so pausatz sobre fractura e dislocacio e torcio.	And this is the manner of the implants in which the Ancients restored them, which they placed on fracture and dislocation and torsion.
Manieyra de emplaustra comu abruejat de restaurament de fractura, convenient a motas compleccios e majorment a las femnas e als efantz, quar es de aquo sobre le qual no ventz calor ni freg: e es que prenguas de polvera de moli, e es la medula de la farina que pen deves le movement de la mola en las paretz del moli.	Method of implantation as an abbreviation of restoration of fracture, convenient for complex joints and majorment to the femurs and to the effigies, because it is about that on which there is no heat nor cold: and it is that you take powder of millet, and it is the marrow of the flour that gives movement to the mill in the walls of the millet.

The species of fractures are many, and their figures are diverse, and the causes are distinct, because some fractures are made by percussion of the spine, and the percussion removes all the bone within the skull, which is behind the bone, thus as it has been said in the fuse, and for this reason this species is called ascial; or the spine insinuates into some part of the bone, and insinuates the flesh of it and does not pass into the posterior of it; and this species of fracture is called absolute levation.

E si le pannicol es retangut quan tu erradiques le os, lahoras cove que prenguas drap de li segon la quantitat de la plagua, e submergeys aquel en oli rozat, e pausa aquel sobre le orrifici de la plagua; e aprop pren autre drap doblat o triplicat e submergeys lu en vi e oli rozat e pausa aquel sobre drap prim e fay aquo al pus leugierament que podes sobre aquel, que no graves le ciphac; e aprop administra sobre aquel liament lat, e no strenhas aquel sino per quantitat que tengua la plagua tant solament.	And if the panniculus is retightened when you eradicate the bone, then it is necessary that you take a drap of oil according to the quantity of the wound, and submerge it in rose oil, and place it over the orifice of the wound; and then take another doubled or tripled drap and submerge it in wine and rose oil and place it over the primary drap and do it as much as possible that you can about that, so that it does not gravitate towards the ciphac; and then administer over that latent liament, and do not stretch it unless for the quantity that the wound has, solely.
E layssa aquel am aquesta cura per un dia o per dos entro que sias segur de apostema caut; e aprop deslia aquel e aprop aministra medicinas am las quals es superflua siccitat, ayssi cum razitz de lin e farina de errs, e polvera de enses e de aristologia, e de semblantz ad aquels.	And leave that on for a day or two until you are secure from apostemic caution; and then remove it and administer medicines as those which are superfluous dryness, thus with linseed oil and flour of barley, and powder of lichen and aristology, and similar to those.
E es que tu fassas de aquestas medicinas polvera que sia pulverizada sobre la plagua, ayssi cum son secas; e universalment, administra en aquel tota medicina de proprietat de la qual es que abstergesca e no mordique.	And it is that you make of these powdered medicines that are pulverized over the wound, thus as they are dry; and universally, administer in all medicine of property of which it is that it cleanses and does not bite.
E guarda te segon la tua vertut que la plagua en la tua curacio sia neta; e no sia en lu surdicia de enguent ni autra; ni no layssas agreguar virulencia en lu; quar quan es ajustada sobre le pannicol del cervel, corromp aquel e poyreys aquel, e accideys sobre le malaute aprop aquo malicia maligna.	And beware according to your virtue that the wound in your cure is clean; and it is not in the surdity of evil intent nor another; nor do not let virulence accumulate in it; because when it is adjusted over the panniculus of the brain, it corrupts it and poisons it, and falls upon the patient with that malignant malice.
E accideys en le ciphac del cap, cum de lu es mondificat le os e majorment quan es menspresada la cura de lu, e es negror en la superficia de lu; e donc considera lahoras si accideys al malaute les accidentz que havem ditz, sapias que es parnicios ses tot dopte.	And it falls upon the ciphac of the head, as of it is mondified bone and majorly when the cure of it is misrepresented, and it is blackened on the surface of it; and therefore consider then that it falls upon the patient with the accidents that we have said, knowing that it is perilous and all doctored.
E si no accideys negror sino de la medicina que es pausada desus, e es en vertut de aquela medicina que fassa aquela negror, lahoras cove que tu prenguas de mel una partida e de oli rozat partidas .iii., e am aquels linieys un drap, e aprop pausa aquel sobre le ciphac; e aprop cura aquel am las specias de curacio que conveneys entro que sia sanat. De restauracio del nas quan es trincat.	On the restoration of the nose when it is broken.
Sapias que no es trencat del nas sino doas partidas ensemps pus sobiranas, o una de aquelas alcunas veguadas, per so quar en lu has dos osses, quar la partida dejos es cartillaginosa, e no es trencada e no accideys a lu sino atricio e tortuositat e sinuitat. E si la fractura es en doas partidas, lahoras tu fay le semblant de aquo.	And if the fracture is in two parts, then you make the similarity to that.

E aprop entromet en la extremitat del nas una meca de drap de li, si la fractura es en una partida, o metz doas calguas, si la fractura es en doas partidas, e sia en la calgua grossitut de tanta quantitat que umpla le trauc del nas. E diysso alcus dels antics restauradors que las calguas sian enfundudas en boder, e sian permudadas en tot dia, mays no es vist a mi; habantz cove que la meca sia enfunduda en album de huou comfit am polvera de moli; e aprop layssa la qualgua entro que l’os sia fermat e sia endurazida la cartillage.	And thus some of the ancient restorers said that the gauzes should be infused in borage, and should be changed every day, but it has not been seen by me; however, it is necessary that the piece be infused in a mixture of honey and powder of moly; and then leave the gauze until the bone is firm and the cartilage is strengthened.

E aquesta causa no es a tu necessaria; e si voles, fay aquo, e si voles, fay calguas.	And this cause is not necessary to you; and if you want, do that, and if you want, do gauzes.

If the bones of the nose are broken with a small fracture or so comminuted, then it is necessary to separate them from those, and extract them with instruments that are convenient for them; and then close the suture, and cure it in such a way that it encarnates and consolidates, and applies convenient emplasters to them.

De restauracio de la mandibula quan es trincada.	On the restoration of the jaw when it is fractured.

De restauracio de la furcula quan es trinquada.	On the restoration of the ankle when it is injured.
Motas veguadas es trencada la furcula de la partida denant deves le muscle, e aquela fractura es fayta en una de tres manieyras.	Similar treatments are broken down into three ways when the ankle is injured from a blow in front of the muscles, and that fracture is made in one of three manners.
Quar o es trencada, o seperada, o es seperada en doas partz otra que no accidan satagias; e es leugier a la restauracio de lu; o es ayssi que accideysso en lu satagias, e es dificil a restauracio de lu; o es ayssi que la fractura es am plagua. De restauracio de la fractura del pietz.	On the restoration of a fracture of the foot.
Le pietz alcunas veguadas es romput en le mieg loc de lu e aquo tart endeve; mays las extremitatz de lu mot endeve que so ciccadas e comminuidas.
